snippet.textDisplay:
Well I guess i will be that guy. I thought this movie as poor, from the terrible plot with dreadfully overplayed scenes of peril, to the quite frustratingly garbage ending, no emotional connection, unlikely moments throughout and the movie felt constantly tinkered with, so much so that it never stands on its merits.


it looks interesting but there is just too much of this 'one shot' idea and sometimes standard film making works and would have elevated those incredible looking scenes beyond being just another scene they tried to be super clever.


Each to their own but I thought this movie was mediocre at best and at worst told a terribly contrived story that fitted into a very strict list of moments that had to be ticked. 4/10 overall.

snippet.textDisplay: Every story goes from A to B. Usually stories are about how interesting the journey is. This movie is reductionism of that journey to only being the ride, like at a theme park. So story development is really lacking. The theme is nihilism - nothing really is accomplished, nothing changes. This makes it a difficult movie to bond to. Private Ryan was completely different while still being about going from A to B. So cinematically great and also it's ability to give you the back seat to a theme park ride, but very anti-story in content. Like a set-piece movie in a 3rd person shooter pc game but without the game story it relies on.

snippet.textDisplay:
I agree with Mark and will say to anyone wanting to see it: just go and see it. It’s not like any ‘war film’ I’ve ever seen (even Dunkirk feels quite different) and there are many moments in it that are real stark reminders that these stories from WW1&2 should continue to be told. I was blown away and gasped many times, the cinematography is stunning and I really felt like I was there with the main characters.
(Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, Richard Madden and Andrew Scott all gave great performances too).

snippet.textDisplay:
spoilers

It’s all beautiful shot but,.....there are some scenes that put me off. After crossing no-mans land and reaching the farm a British convoy suddenly appears. I mean, how? And these guys are the only two who can warn the troops?

A pilot who is saved from a horrible death decides to stab one of his saviers in the gut? German bad, British good. What a cliché.

And crossing the bridge, fully exposed, he gets shot at by a sniper. Who has an hour to aim and take the shot. And misses over and over again. How could the german miss? The messenger takes a random shot and hits the german. Really?

The town sequence was weird. The woman, the baby (looked quite well fed) and again getting shot at a million times and all misses.

snippet.textDisplay:
Just got back home from seeing this at the BFI IMAX. I love films, but often don't see them at the cinema and sometimes regret having missed the 'big screen experience' when I finally get round to seeing them on a tv screen. I am SO GLAD I made the effort to see this one.


If you are interested in 1917, please, please do yourself a favour and watch it on the biggest screen you can. This might sound a bit over the top, but it's one of the most profound cinematic experiences I've had. It's absolutely breathtaking. Go see.

snippet.textDisplay: The scenario in the film is set during the German retreat to the Hindenburg Line. The Germans did wreck everything left behind in the abandoned zone. That is well documented.  What the film doesn't capture well is the depth of the Forward Edge of the Battlefield. The German Army, more than any other WWI Army, had long range artillery that could cover miles of depth. The final battle scenario, where you find aid stations in an open field, seems wrong, such a makeshift field hospital would have been far to the rear to avoid artillery. Also, the trench line occupied in the end, in the chalk, would have taken quite some time to dig, especially within artillery range of the Hindenburg Line. The scenario seemed to imply the two battalions pressed too far ahead and were about to attack, but there's no way they would have had time to dig those trenches. If they were attacking straight from their assembly areas in the woods it would have made more sense.

snippet.textDisplay:
Spoilers



That initial 15-20 minute sequence when they go over the top, across no mans land, into the german trench culminating with the trip wire going off and having to escape was a pure masterclass in building and releasing tension. The rest of the film is very good but that was the standout moment for me.

snippet.textDisplay: So... a General personally briefs two Lance Corporals (NCOs) on a task to intercept a Battalion. Have I missed something? Isn’t this an absolutely incredibly absurd plot? Surreal. In practice a General wouldn’t talk to an NCO, let alone give then direct orders. Wouldn’t the General’s staff officers instruct a commissioned officer, by paper order or phone (if the lines were ok) to take a patrol of about 6 men to do the job. The line about the NCOs’ personal links wouldn’t have mattered at all. And the fact that it’s a Battalion they’re intercepting is important - that’s a very substantial force and their loss might have cost the General his job. And 1,600 men is a overly large Battalion? Weren’t they about 1,000 incl. all support staff? Or did they expand by 1917? Yes, individual soldiers used as messengers were a universal feature of WW1. But this is a fantasy plot?

snippet.textDisplay:
I thought cinema died in 1993 with the death of Federico Fellini. This movie gives me hope that I actually was wrong.

The writer/director is cruelly squeezing our souls dry each and every second, for two long hours.

It's amazing how Sir Sam Mendes sublimates the horror of death (over the horse's carcass I actually hold my breath!!!) into the pure heavenly bliss of the final moments under that fabulous Axis Mundi tree. In those moments the movie becomes a heartbreaking paean to family and our inalienable humanity.

Thank you, Sir Sam Mendes, for destroying the mystique of "glamour and honor". Thank you for saying "It's just a piece of tin that nobody cares about".

The movie is like a stroll in the famous Peter Bruegel painting "The Triumph of Death".

The days of the action (6 and 7 April 1917) are very mysterious.

All I can say is that 6 April 1917 is the day the USA declared war to Germany in WWI... And 7 April is the day most historians accept as the day of the Crucifixion ( year 30 AD)...

All the movie seems to be under the hallmark of the famous Russian director Andrei Tarkowsky...

All in all, it's good to have a trumpet player as wife...

snippet.textDisplay: Just saw 1917 today. Amazing on several levels.  Cinematography is amazing...I don't know how they shot many scenes. Overt messages, of course, about the atrocities of war and the responsibility of duty are there. But am I wrong to think there was a more subtle, but overall more important, message about the importance of family, punctuated throughout the film and emphasized in the night scene with the baby? (No spoilers!) It makes me wonder what is Corporal Schofield's back story, more specifically what is/was his relationship like with his mother....as I believe this adds to his sense of duty to see his mission through. This may not be a movie everyone finds entertaining, but how anyone could give the movie a negative review is beyond me.

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry,  but I left the Imax underwhelmed, maybe  I was expecting too much given the reviews.  Yes, the cinematography was good, but the set scenes were mostly implausible. For me, it started with the explosion in the underground gallery, after which it got more and more implausible as the film moved on. I know my comment bucks this thread, but that's just my personal take on 1917 the movie. I think Saving Private Ryan was a better film.

snippet.textDisplay:
Bloodless? He did say bloodless? It's been over a hundred years and the worst accounts are still shied away from.
Accounts of men sleeping in fetid pools stained by chemical weapons and toxic debris, surrounded and filled by thousands of bodies (and parts thereof) that can't retrieved where men have to shit where they lie because they don't want to die. (in the abstract landscapes of Passchendaele)
Accounts of machine gunners carving holes into the piles of dead with their bullets to get a clear shot, with the germans being so relentless in their charge to death. (Liège?)
WW1 should be a sick gore flick. Why isn't someone making the surreal hyperbole of this already surreal violence?

I'll probably like this movie anyway, so whatever I guess.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wrote the script and picked the cast for this film around the time I wrote Knives Out.  Sam Mendes, like Todd Bunzl, Martin Scorsese, Rian Johnson, Brad Pitt, Jeff Bezos, George Lucas and Taika Waititi are not fond of accrediting the original writer especially when Bezos has a grudge and Lucas fears my surname as he is a tight fisted Palpatine level Satanist.

I wanted Deakins as soon as I saw the Bladerunner sequel and wanted a Children of Men style take in WW1 trench warfare as that would be both an artistic triumph and a crowd pleaser for all the old musty farts in movie awards and artistic circles spending government funds on what they subjectively deem "art".

I wrote the script with reference to William Blake and Phillip Schofield as influential men, the first to me was a mad genius and the second was a name that carries weight for working age adults.  The cast were men who have acted well or stuck out to me as excellent character actors that I could write specifically for.

The key point to prove I wrote this script is that I studied Blake and WW1 poetry in my AQA A Level in English Literature in Bedford College around the time I wrote There Will Be Blood and not too long before I wrote the rest of my War on Terror trilogy of Iron Man 1 and The Dark Knight before a ten year hiatus that ended with:

Joker an Origin Story and The Irishman as first a recalling of my tragic bitter life experiences as an Autistic savant be it on the bus, dreaming of acceptance, longing for a positive father figure and the nihilistic disaffection I was trapped in.  The Irishman was all of that with tips to Godfather, my work history, humour and tragedy.

I also wrote Ad Astra, Booksmart and Uncut Gems, not that anyone will believe a gentile in the heady world of ultra pro-Zionist media as they drift ignorantly along echo chambers of sycophantic geriatric worship for semi-literate Scorsese and the exulted engorged ego's of wrinkly hard headed Hollywood Heavyweights.

snippet.textDisplay:
Few things I don't like: (i) the media narrative that the film is 'one continuous shot'. It's not. (ii) Mendes seems to have had a Bond hangover -an ordinary British Tommy is not James Bond (iii) the 'milk' coincidence (iv) the singing scene - as if that would happen! Leave the beautiful vocal for the credits

Loved the tunnel scene and the village scene.
